body: Thanks for the report. I am going to set this as a low priority bug since the impact doesn't seem to be large and it might be difficult to fix. If this bug impacts you in a meaningful way, let me know and I will increase the priority.

I'm using opencover.ui for visualizing code coverage in Visual Studio. opencover.ui is relying on the full assembly path (in the element test-suite).
(I developed a small patch to use opencover.ui with nunit 3.0)
I can fix this at the same time as #1189

issue.title: Issue 1189
issue.body:
The intention here was to fix #1189 and fix #1195 in the same PR, since they appeared to impact the same code. However, it looks like #1189 is actually not a problem at all. @rprouse if you review this, hold off merging until I hear back from the author of #1189.

"While I was at it" I noticed that the V2 xml contains empty reason elements and properties for the reason a test is skipped, when the reason is not provided. This turned out to echo the 3.0 xml output, which I have fixed in the second commit.

issue.title: Support for NUnit 3.X
issue.body:
This adds support for NUnit 3.x. Tests are discovered by the existing opencover.ui-way.
The current release of NUnit 3.0.1 contains a bug affecting the assembly name in the output file.
There will be a bug fix in release 3.2. (nunit/nunit#1195). Until then the executed tests will not show up as executed in the opencover.ui test explorer. Nevertheless the coverage is displayed.

body:
Your comment is appearing in my email and not on GitHub, so I'll answer by
email. If you know that you did anything special with this comment, which
might have caused it not to appear on GH, please let me know as I've been
trying to figure out why this happens with some people's comments.

Anyway... you are quite right. The issue that was reported against the
console runner was fixed. I should have remembered to make the same fix to
NUnitLite, in case anyone needed it. I'm reopening this temporarily until I
get that fixed as well.

On Wed, Mar 30, 2016 at 9:10 AM, linquize notifications@github.com wrote:

> But it is not fixed when using nunitlite 3.2
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were assigned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1195#issuecomment-203506773

I have to say that this issue is not completely fixed, if you compare xmls form @bunnu comment, there are two differences:
1. `<test-suite name` attribute
2. `<test-results name` attribute

In NUnit 3.2.1 only first one fixed, second is still appears - test-results name attribute is empty.

@CharliePoole I don't know should I create new issue on this or you will reopen this one ?
On my phone, so limited search, but I am pretty sure the second was reported and fixed in 3.4 which will be out soon.

Found an issue #1543 about that, thanks.
Wait for nunit 3.4 to resolve.
